paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Can intratumoral mRNA vaccination sensitize tumors to immune checkpoint blockade and does that align with outcomes in vaccinated patients receiving ICI?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Multiple murine tumor models received intratumoral mRNA vaccine plus anti-PD-L1 across pooled repeat experiments.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohorts
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Matched control conditions included vaccine-only, ICI-only, and vehicle arms across pooled murine experiments.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective metastatic patient cohort compared prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status during ICI treatment.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Patients in the retrospective cohort who had prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Patients in the retrospective cohort without prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination for comparison.

major_limitations: The human analysis was retrospective and non-randomized, so residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniform across settings.
